notes: Fourth generation A3 (8Y platform, 2020–present). US market offers sedan and Sportback body styles. 2.0L TFSI engine with mild-hybrid 48V system. AWD quattro available on select trims. Data sourced from Wikipedia Audi A3 article, January 2025 revision.
Fifth generation A4 facelift (B9, 2020–2023). Updated MMI infotainment and mild-hybrid 48V system. quattro AWD standard on S4. Data sourced from Wikipedia Audi A4 article, January 2025 revision.

Second generation A5 facelift (F5, 2020–2024). Mild-hybrid 48V system on TFSI engines. quattro AWD standard on S5 and available on other trims. Data sourced from Wikipedia Audi A5 article, January 2025 revision.

Fifth generation A6 (C8, 2018–present). 48V mild-hybrid system standard on all engines. Available plug-in hybrid (55 TFSI e) with 14.1 kWh battery and 367 hp combined. quattro AWD standard on V6+ models. Data sourced from Wikipedia Audi A6 article, January 2025 revision.

Second generation A7 Sportback (C8, 2018–present). 48V mild-hybrid system standard. Available plug-in hybrid (55 TFSI e) with 14.1 kWh battery. quattro AWD standard. Data sourced from Wikipedia Audi A7 article, January 2025 revision.

Fourth generation A8 facelift (D5, 2022–present). 48V mild-hybrid system standard. Available plug-in hybrid (60 TFSI e) with 14.1 kWh battery and 449 hp combined. quattro AWD with rear-biased torque split standard. Level 3 autonomous driving hardware (not activated in US). Data sourced from Wikipedia Audi A8 article, January 2025 revision.
Second generation Q3 (F3, 2019–present). Built on MQB platform. quattro AWD available. Data sourced from Wikipedia Audi Q3 article, January 2025 revision.

First generation Q4 e-tron (2021–present). Built on MEB electric platform. 77 kWh battery (net 76.6 kWh usable). High-voltage 400V architecture. Requires EV-certified technicians for battery service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Audi Q4 e-tron article, January 2025 revision.

Second generation Q5 facelift (FY, 2021–present). 48V mild-hybrid system standard. Available plug-in hybrid (55 TFSI e) with 14.1 kWh battery. quattro AWD standard. Data sourced from Wikipedia Audi Q5 article, January 2025 revision.

Second generation Q7 facelift (4M, 2020–present). 48V mild-hybrid system standard. Available plug-in hybrid (55 TFSI e) with 17.3 kWh battery. Three-row seating. quattro AWD standard. Data sourced from Wikipedia Audi Q7 article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 4.0L TFSI V8 twin-turbo (591 hp RS Q8)
notes: First generation Q8 (4M, 2018–present). Coupe SUV variant of Q7. 48V mild-hybrid system standard. Available plug-in hybrid (55 TFSI e) with 17.3 kWh battery. quattro AWD standard. Data sourced from Wikipedia Audi Q8 article, January 2025 revision.

Renamed e-tron (formerly Audi e-tron, 2019–2022). Built on MLB evo platform. 114 kWh battery (net 106 kWh usable). High-voltage 400V architecture with 150 kW DC fast charging. Requires EV-certified technicians. Data sourced from Wikipedia Audi e-tron article, January 2025 revision.

engines: Dual electric motors (637 hp RS e-tron GT)
notes: First generation e-tron GT (2021–present). Shares J1 platform with Porsche Taycan. 93.4 kWh battery (net 83.7 kWh usable). High-voltage 800V architecture with 270 kW DC fast charging. 2-speed transmission for improved efficiency. Requires EV-certified technicians. Data sourced from Wikipedia Audi e-tron GT article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 2.5L TFSI I5 turbo (394 hp TT RS)
notes: Third generation TT (8S, 2014–2023). Production ended July 2023. Virtual Cockpit standard. Manual transmission on base models. quattro AWD standard on TT RS. Data sourced from Wikipedia Audi TT article, January 2025 revision.

Second generation R8 (4S, 2015–2023). Production ended in 2023. Mid-engine supercar. Naturally aspirated V10 engine. quattro AWD with rear-biased torque split. Aluminum Space Frame construction. Requires specialized service access for mid-engine layout. Data sourced from Wikipedia Audi R8 article, January 2025 revision.
Fourth generation S3 (8Y platform, 2020–present). Performance variant of A3. quattro AWD standard. Data sourced from Wikipedia Audi S3 article, January 2025 revision.

Fourth generation RS3 (8Y platform, 2022–present). High-performance variant of A3. Legendary 2.5L inline-five turbo engine. quattro AWD with torque vectoring. Data sourced from Wikipedia Audi RS3 article, January 2025 revision.
